questions.question: A company estimates variable consideration for a contract with uncertainty. Under ASC 606, the constraint requires that variable consideration be included only to the extent that:

options.A: It is virtually certain to be collected
options.B: It is probable that a significant revenue reversal will not occur
options.C: The customer has accepted the goods or services

questions.explanation: The constraint on variable consideration requires that amounts be included in the transaction price only to the extent it is probable that a significant reversal in cumulative revenue recognized will not occur when uncertainty is resolved.
questions.tip: Variable consideration constraint: Include if probable NO significant reversal. Conservative approach to uncertain amounts.

questions.question: A company sells products through a third-party retailer. Which factor most strongly indicates the company is acting as principal rather than agent?

options.A: The retailer sets the selling price
options.B: The company bears inventory risk before transfer to the customer
options.C: The company receives a fixed commission

questions.explanation: A principal controls goods/services before transfer to the customer. Primary indicators include: inventory risk, pricing discretion, and primary responsibility for fulfillment. Bearing inventory risk strongly suggests principal status.
questions.tip: Principal = control before transfer. Key: inventory risk, pricing power, fulfillment responsibility. Agent = earns commission.

questions.subtopic: Lower of Cost or Net Realizable Value
questions.question: Inventory has a cost of $50,000, selling price of $55,000, and estimated selling costs of $8,000. Under LCNRV, the inventory should be reported at:
questions.explanation: NRV = Selling price - Estimated costs to complete and sell = $55,000 - $8,000 = $47,000. Compare to cost ($50,000). Report at lower amount: $47,000.
questions.tip: NRV = Selling price - Completion/selling costs. Compare to cost, use lower amount.

questions.question: A company using perpetual weighted average has beginning inventory of 100 units @ $10 and purchases 200 units @ $13. After the purchase, the weighted average cost per unit is:
questions.tip: Weighted average = Total cost ÷ Total units. Recalculate after each purchase in perpetual system.

questions.question: Which cost should be capitalized as part of the cost of a self-constructed asset?

options.B: Interest on debt used to finance construction
options.D: Training costs for operating the asset

questions.explanation: Capitalized costs include direct materials, direct labor, variable overhead, and interest during construction (if qualifying asset). G&A, abnormal waste, and training are expensed.
questions.tip: Capitalize: Direct costs + interest during construction. Expense: G&A, abnormal waste, training, start-up costs.

questions.question: A company has a legal obligation to remove equipment at the end of its useful life. At inception, the company should:

options.A: Expense the estimated removal cost immediately
options.B: Record a liability at fair value and increase the asset cost
options.C: Disclose the obligation but not record it
options.D: Record a liability only when removal occurs

questions.explanation: An ARO is initially recorded at fair value (present value of future costs). The offsetting debit increases the carrying amount of the related asset, which is then depreciated over its useful life.
questions.tip: ARO: Record liability at PV, increase asset cost. Accrete liability over time, depreciate added asset cost.

questions.question: A company owns 18% of another company's voting stock. The equity method should be used if:

options.B: The investor can demonstrate significant influence despite lower ownership
options.C: Only if the investee is profitable
options.D: The investor has a board seat and owns exactly 20%

questions.explanation: The 20% threshold is a presumption, not an absolute rule. Significant influence can exist below 20% (board representation, policy participation, material transactions) or may not exist above 20% (concentrated opposing ownership).
questions.tip: 20% = presumption of significant influence, not requirement. Look at actual influence indicators.

questions.question: A company holds trading securities that increased in value by $10,000 during the year. This unrealized gain is reported:

options.B: As a direct adjustment to retained earnings
options.C: In net income on the income statement
options.D: Only when the securities are sold

questions.explanation: Trading securities are measured at fair value with unrealized gains and losses reported in net income. This differs from AFS debt securities, which report unrealized amounts in OCI.
questions.tip: Trading = FV through income. AFS debt = FV through OCI. Equity investments = generally FV through income.

questions.question: A lessee should classify a lease as a finance lease if:

options.A: The lease term is less than 75% of the asset's economic life
options.B: The present value of lease payments is 85% of the asset's fair value
options.C: Ownership transfers to the lessee at the end of the lease
options.D: The asset has no residual value

questions.explanation: Finance lease criteria (any one): ownership transfer, bargain purchase option, lease term ≥75% of economic life, PV of payments ≥90% of fair value, or asset is specialized with no alternative use to lessor.
questions.tip: Finance lease = any ONE criterion met. 75% life, 90% PV, transfer, BPO, or specialized asset.

questions.question: A lease modification should be accounted for as a separate contract when the modification:

options.B: Extends the lease term without adding scope
options.C: Grants an additional right of use not in the original lease at standalone price

questions.explanation: A lease modification is a separate contract if: (1) it increases scope by adding the right to use assets not in original lease, AND (2) consideration increases by an amount commensurate with standalone price for the additional right of use.
questions.tip: Separate contract: New scope + standalone price. Otherwise, remeasure the existing lease.

questions.question: When bonds are issued at a premium and the effective interest method is used, the interest expense each period:

options.B: Increases over the life of the bond
options.C: Decreases over the life of the bond

questions.explanation: With a premium, carrying value decreases as premium is amortized. Interest expense = Carrying value × Market rate. As carrying value decreases, interest expense decreases each period.
questions.tip: Premium: CV decreases, interest expense decreases. Discount: CV increases, interest expense increases.

questions.question: A company retires bonds with a carrying value of $485,000 by paying $500,000 in cash. The company should recognize:

options.B: A loss of $15,000

questions.explanation: Gain/loss on early extinguishment = Carrying value - Cash paid = $485,000 - $500,000 = $(15,000) loss. Paying more than carrying value results in a loss.
questions.tip: Extinguishment: CV - Cash paid. Positive = gain, Negative = loss. Reported in income.

questions.question: Under the cost method, when treasury stock is reissued above its acquisition cost, the excess is credited to:

options.A: Gain on sale of treasury stock
options.B: Retained earnings
options.C: Additional paid-in capital from treasury stock

questions.explanation: Treasury stock transactions never result in gains or losses on the income statement. When reissued above cost, the excess goes to APIC-Treasury Stock. Reissuance below cost reduces APIC-Treasury or Retained Earnings.
questions.tip: Treasury stock: No income statement impact. Above cost = APIC. Below cost = reduce APIC then RE.

questions.question: A company with 100,000 shares outstanding (par $1, market $15) declares a 10% stock dividend. What amount is transferred from retained earnings?
questions.explanation: Small stock dividend (<20-25%): Transfer fair market value from RE. Shares issued = 100,000 × 10% = 10,000. RE reduction = 10,000 × $15 market value = $150,000.
questions.tip: Small stock dividend = FMV transfer. Large stock dividend (>20-25%) = par value transfer only.

questions.question: A valuation allowance against a deferred tax asset is required when:

options.A: The DTA relates to an operating loss carryforward
options.B: It is more likely than not that some portion of the DTA will not be realized
options.C: The company has reported losses for two consecutive years
options.D: The DTA exceeds deferred tax liabilities

questions.explanation: A valuation allowance reduces DTA to the amount more likely than not (>50%) to be realized. Sources of future taxable income include: reversing DTLs, future taxable income, tax planning strategies, and carryback potential.
questions.tip: Valuation allowance = when realization is NOT more likely than not. Assess all sources of future taxable income.

questions.question: Intraperiod tax allocation requires that income tax expense be allocated to:

options.B: Continuing operations, discontinued operations, OCI, and equity adjustments

questions.explanation: Intraperiod allocation allocates total tax expense/benefit among: continuing operations, discontinued operations, other comprehensive income, and items charged/credited directly to equity.
questions.tip: Intraperiod = within a period, among income statement/OCI/equity items. Interperiod = between periods (deferrals).

questions.question: A city's water utility that charges user fees should be accounted for in which fund type?

options.B: Special revenue fund

questions.explanation: Enterprise funds account for activities where fees are charged to external users (water, sewer, parking, airports). They use accrual accounting like businesses. Internal service funds serve other government departments.
questions.tip: Enterprise = fees from external users. Internal service = services to other departments. Both are proprietary funds.

questions.question: Governmental funds use the current financial resources measurement focus. This means they report:

options.A: All economic resources including long-term assets
options.B: Current assets and current liabilities, focusing on near-term spendable resources

questions.explanation: Current financial resources focus reports current assets and current liabilities. Long-term assets and liabilities are not reported in governmental fund statements (but appear in government-wide statements).
questions.tip: Governmental funds: Current financial resources = near-term spendable. Proprietary funds: Economic resources = all assets/liabilities.

questions.question: Which fund balance classification represents amounts constrained by external parties?

options.B: Restricted

questions.explanation: Fund balance hierarchy: Nonspendable (can't spend), Restricted (external constraints), Committed (government's highest authority), Assigned (government's intent), Unassigned (residual). Restricted = creditors, grantors, laws.
questions.tip: Restricted = external constraints. Committed = self-imposed by highest authority. Assigned = intended use.

questions.question: A donor promises $100,000 if the NFP raises matching funds. This contribution is:

options.A: Recognized immediately as revenue with donor restriction
options.B: Recognized when the matching funds are raised (condition met)

questions.explanation: A matching requirement is a condition (barrier). Conditional contributions are not recognized until the condition is substantially met. Once met, recognize as revenue with or without donor restriction based on any remaining restrictions.
questions.tip: Condition = barrier to entitlement. Restriction = purpose/time limit after entitled. Condition first, then consider restrictions.

questions.question: An NFP receives $50,000 restricted for building construction. When the building is completed, the NFP should:

options.A: Keep the amount in net assets with donor restrictions permanently
options.B: Reclassify from with restrictions to without restrictions
options.C: Return unused funds to the donor
options.D: Record a gain on the income statement

questions.explanation: When purpose restrictions are satisfied (building completed), net assets are reclassified from 'with donor restrictions' to 'without donor restrictions.' This is shown as a release from restrictions.
questions.tip: Restriction satisfied = reclassify from with to without restrictions. Show as release in statement of activities.

questions.question: Under the indirect method, depreciation expense is added back to net income because:

options.A: It represents a source of cash
options.B: It reduced net income but did not use cash

questions.explanation: Depreciation is a non-cash expense that reduced net income. Adding it back adjusts for this non-cash reduction. Depreciation does not generate cash—it's simply reversing its income statement effect.
questions.tip: Indirect method: Add back non-cash expenses (depreciation, amortization). They reduced NI but didn't use cash.

questions.question: Sales revenue was $500,000. Accounts receivable increased by $30,000. Cash collected from customers was:
questions.explanation: Cash collected = Sales - Increase in AR (or + Decrease in AR). $500,000 - $30,000 = $470,000. An increase in AR means some sales weren't collected yet.
questions.tip: Cash from customers: Sales ± change in AR. AR increased = less cash collected than sales.

questions.question: Direct costs of a business combination (legal fees, due diligence) are:

options.B: Added to the purchase price

questions.explanation: Under the acquisition method, acquisition-related costs (finder's fees, advisory, legal, accounting, valuation) are expensed as incurred. They are not part of consideration transferred or goodwill.
questions.tip: Acquisition costs = expense. Stock issuance costs = reduce APIC. These are not included in purchase price.

questions.question: In a business combination where less than 100% is acquired, the non-controlling interest may be measured at:

options.B: Fair value or proportionate share of net identifiable assets

questions.explanation: NCI can be measured at either: (1) fair value (full goodwill method), or (2) proportionate share of acquiree's identifiable net assets (partial goodwill method). This is an accounting policy choice.
questions.tip: NCI at acquisition: FV (full goodwill) or proportionate share (partial goodwill). US GAAP allows both.

questions.question: A foreign subsidiary's functional currency is the US dollar (parent's currency). The subsidiary's financial statements require:

options.A: Translation using the current rate method
options.B: Remeasurement using the temporal method

questions.explanation: When functional currency equals the reporting currency, remeasurement (temporal method) is used. Monetary items at current rate, non-monetary at historical rate. Gains/losses go to income, not OCI.
questions.tip: Functional = Reporting currency: Remeasure (temporal), gains/losses in income. Functional ≠ Reporting: Translate (current rate), CTA in OCI.

questions.question: A US company purchases inventory from a foreign supplier for 10,000 euros when the rate is $1.10. At payment, the rate is $1.15. The company records:

options.B: A transaction loss of $500
options.C: No gain or loss—inventory is adjusted

questions.explanation: The company owes euros. When the dollar weakens (more dollars per euro), it costs more to settle the liability. Loss = 10,000 × ($1.15 - $1.10) = $500 transaction loss in income.
questions.tip: Payable in FC: Dollar weakens = loss (costs more to pay). Dollar strengthens = gain. Receivable is opposite.

questions.question: In a qualifying cash flow hedge, the effective portion of the gain or loss on the derivative is reported in:

options.B: Other comprehensive income until the hedged item affects earnings
options.D: As an adjustment to the hedged asset or liability

questions.explanation: Cash flow hedge: Effective portion goes to OCI and is reclassified to earnings when the hedged item (forecasted transaction) affects earnings. Ineffective portion goes directly to earnings.
questions.tip: Cash flow hedge: Effective → OCI → earnings when hedged item hits earnings. Fair value hedge: Both to earnings immediately.

questions.conceptTested: Components of net periodic pension cost
questions.question: Which component increases net periodic pension cost?

options.B: Service cost

questions.explanation: Net periodic pension cost = Service cost + Interest cost + Amortization of prior service cost + Amortization of net loss - Expected return on plan assets - Amortization of net gain. Service cost always increases expense.
questions.tip: Pension expense increases: Service cost, interest cost, amortizing losses/prior service cost. Decreases: Return on assets, amortizing gains.

questions.conceptTested: Items recorded in AOCI for pensions
questions.question: Which pension-related item is initially recorded in other comprehensive income?

options.B: Interest cost
options.C: Actuarial gains and losses arising during the period

questions.explanation: Actuarial gains/losses and prior service cost from plan amendments are recorded in OCI, then amortized to pension expense over time. Service cost, interest cost, and expected return are in pension expense directly.
questions.tip: Pension items in OCI: Actuarial gains/losses, prior service cost. Amortized to expense via corridor or faster method.

questions.question: A loss contingency should be accrued when the loss is:

options.B: Probable and estimable

questions.explanation: Loss contingencies are accrued when: (1) probable (likely to occur), AND (2) reasonably estimable. If probable but not estimable, or only reasonably possible, disclose but don't accrue.
questions.tip: Accrue: Probable + Estimable. Disclose: Probable but not estimable, or Reasonably possible. Remote: Generally no disclosure.

questions.question: A company has a lawsuit pending where it expects to receive $1 million. The gain contingency should be:

options.B: Recorded when probable and estimable
options.C: Disclosed but not recognized until realized

questions.explanation: Gain contingencies are not recognized until realized to avoid premature recognition of income. They may be disclosed if probability is high, but recognition awaits resolution.
questions.tip: Gain contingencies: Disclose if appropriate, but don't recognize until realized. Conservative treatment.

questions.conceptTested: Type I vs Type II subsequent events
questions.question: After year-end but before issuance, a company learns a major customer declared bankruptcy. The receivable existed at year-end. This is a:

options.A: Nonrecognized subsequent event requiring disclosure only
options.B: Recognized subsequent event requiring adjustment to financial statements
options.C: Non-event because it occurred after year-end

questions.explanation: Type I (recognized) events provide additional evidence about conditions existing at the balance sheet date. The receivable existed, so the bankruptcy provides evidence about its collectibility at year-end—adjust the allowance.
questions.tip: Type I = conditions existed at B/S date, adjust statements. Type II = conditions arose after B/S date, disclose only.

questions.question: Under US GAAP, interim periods are viewed primarily as:

options.A: Integral parts of the annual period
options.B: Discrete standalone periods
options.D: Management reports not subject to GAAP

questions.explanation: US GAAP treats interim periods as integral parts of the annual period. Some costs are allocated across quarters. However, revenue recognition generally follows discrete period concepts (recognize when earned).
questions.tip: Interim periods: Integral for most expenses (allocate costs), discrete for revenue (recognize when earned).

questions.question: Under IFRS, a company using the revaluation model for PPE records an increase in asset value by:

options.A: Crediting a gain in profit or loss
options.B: Crediting revaluation surplus in OCI (unless reversing prior loss)

questions.explanation: IFRS revaluation increases: Credit revaluation surplus in OCI (and equity). Exception: If reversing a prior revaluation decrease in P&L, the increase goes to P&L first. US GAAP doesn't allow upward revaluation.
questions.tip: IFRS revaluation: Increases → OCI (revaluation surplus). Decreases → P&L (unless reversing prior OCI increase).
